awd_titl_txt: Moduli of Stable Log Maps and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This project lies in the area of algebraic geometry, a branch of mathematics studying algebraic varieties, namely, the set of solutions of polynomial equations. The topic of this project is closely related to string theory from physics, where algebraic varieties are used to describe a piece of our universe. An amazing fact is that collections of varieties of certain type inside another bigger one are themselves varieties. The study of such collections of varieties provides not only powerfully tools to study problems in geometry in mathematics, but also useful methods to extract invariants interesting to physicists. The main topic of this project is aimed at developing a mathematical tool to calculate these invariants from string physics. Other topics of this project focus on using the above developed tool to solve problems from geometry and number theory. 

The major topic of this project is to study Gromov-Witten invariants via logarithmic smooth degenerations. The short term goal is to develop the theory of punctured maps which are, roughly speaking, stable logarithmic maps with "poles". The long term goal is to prove an effective degeneration formula which expresses Gromov-Witten invariants as a combination of invariants from punctured maps as the basic building blocks. Further topics of this project include (1) studying Teichmuller dynamics via the logarithmic compactification; and (2) studying density problem of integral points over function fields of algebraic curves. Both topics are further applications of the theory of stable logarithmic maps.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project lies in the field of algebraic geometry, a branch of mathematics studying shapes of solutions of polynomial equations called algebraic varieties. The main focus of this project is the enumerative geometry on counting Riemann surfaces in algebraic varieties.

The shapes of Riemann surfaces include for example a two dimensional sphere or the surface of a donut.  It is a centuries-old interesting question of computing the number of Riemann surfaces with certain given shapes inside an algebraic variety satisfying some incidence conditions such as passing through a set of points. In morden algebraic geometry, countings of Riemann surfaces has been developed rigorously to the so called Gromov-Witten invariants. These are invariants from string theory in physics to describe the structure of the universe, and they have deep connections to many areas of mathematics such as complex geometry, symplectic geometry, and number theory. Despite many important progresses during past several decades, effectively computing Gromov-Witten invariants remains to be a difficult problem. The main purpose of this project is to develope an approach to studying and computing Gromov-Witten invariants via degenerations of algebraic varieties --- a method to break a complicated algebraic variety to unions of simpler ones. In the project, the PI and his collaborators have constructed a new type of invariants on these simpler pieces, called the punctured invariants, and show that the Gromov-Witten invariants of the original algebraic variety can be recovered from these simpler pieces. 

The punctured invariants developed in this project already have several important applications. For example, they have been used crucially in computing higher genus Gromov-Witten invariants of quintic three-folds by Felix--Guo--Ruan, and in the intrinsic mirror construction of Gross--Siebert. 

During this project, the PI supervised one graduate student to finish a Ph.D thesis on the geometry of A1-curves, and mentored a post-doc on studying logarithmic Gromov-Witten theory, both along the line of the proposed project.  The PI has co-organized several workshops, conferences  and two seminar series to bring together researchers from both enumerative geomery moduli spaces, and to provide training opportunities to junior researchers. He has given a number of invited research talks to disseminate the results of this project to the research community.


Last Modified: 11/04/2021
Modified by: Qile Chen
